indicator.title: Output Indicator

baseline.comment: - Crisis and Recovery Mapping and Analysis (CRMA) exercise completed in West Darfur state and reports and maps produced; but no village specific CRMA exercise - No Conflict assessment conducted in any of the four return villages in West Darfur State -Widespread destruction of livelihoods and productive assets in most villages in Darfur during the 9 years of the conflict; - No adequate support has been provided -Widespread destruction of basic community infrastructure,no adequate support has been provided. -No formal/ organised structures for coordinating / managing villagesâ€™ assets

actual.comment: 1.1) CRMA exercises were completed in four target villages and 21 key livelihoods and infrastructure interventions identified and implemented (see output 3). A gender disaggregated report including four (4) community resource maps and 4 development maps and plans were produced as an outcome of the CRMA exercises. Some 95% of the community resource persons involved in the process stated that they are now able to identify risks and needs and as well as identifying resources and opportunities to improve livelihoods and community development. 1.2) Conflict assessment and analysis were conducted in the four target villages. Key risk factors and conflict flash points were identified through the exercise. The exercise identified the risk of conflicts from the competition over limited natural resources and basic services such as water, fuelwood, grinding mills, grazing and agricultural land and conflict between nomads and sedentary farmers in the return villages. It also highlighted the distances to key resources and the risk to women. As a result appropriate interventions were identified, planned and implemented. 2.1) 769 vulnerable HHs in 4 villages now own and use productive assets such as donkey carts, treadle pumps, goats, and seeds and tools as a result of the Project. Details of the assets provided are listed in the table 1 and 2 above. 2.2) Some 513 HHs own and use fuel efficient stoves through the support of the Project. Out of these, 158 people have been trained as trainers in the production of fuel efficient stoves and in turn, they have trained up to 435 beneficiaries of which 86% were women. 3.1 Twenty One (21) community infrastructures were rehabilitated/ constructed and used. These include: ï‚§ 1 water pump constructed, 3 water pumps were rehabilitated, 2 hand dug- well constructed; ï‚§ 4 markets were rehabilitated; ï‚§ 7 grinding mills made available ï‚§ 1 oil extracting machine established and used; ï‚§ 1 storage facility was constructed ï‚§ One building with 3 ro

target.comment: Project not active

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1.Number of Peace and Development Councils established and effective in their function

target.comment: 1.1. 5 additional CBRM councils functional, including in Katila 1.2 50 % of community members have access to CBRMs 1.3: Project target 90% 1:4: Project target 80% 1.5: At least 1 representative of vulnerable groups in each CBRM 2.1: 5 community based management mechanisms for natural resources estab-lished 2.2: at least 5 social service infrastructure rehabilitated /newly built 2.3: 50 % of community members stating an increase in the number of interactions between diverse communities through basic services 2.4 At least 3 community social service infrastructure rehabilitated/ constructed. 3.1: 1 collective interactions of conflict resolution mechanisms with state and regional level mechanisms 3.2: 3 collective interactions of conflict resolutions mechanisms with higher level mechanism

actual.comment: Target 1.1: Four (4) new Peace Development Councils were established within the year: one in Idd el Fursan and one in Ku-bum, as well as two (2) sub committees in Kubum. Additional two PDCs will be established in Katilla in the Q1 2015. This brings to a total of 14 PDCS formed since the project started in January 2012. The capacity of PDC members was strengthened through 2 training workshops on conflict management and community planning. The trainings have built the confidence of the mem-bers and the councils are now operating with minimal backstop-ping from the DCRC team. Target 1.2 & 1.3: Within 2014, 100% of the disputes submitted to the PDCs were successfully resolved and settled. The PDCs resolved approximately 45 cases and became accessible by 100% of all the community members. Target 1.4: The project conducted a perception survey in Mukjar, Kubum and Idd Elfursan and as a result over 80% of commu-nity members who were interviewed reported that the project activities positively supported the restoration of trust and confi-dence. Target 1.5: Reported from PDCs: â€¢ Salamat tribe: 2 â€¢ Four tribe: 4 â€¢ Bani Halba: 5 â€¢ Women: 5 â€¢ Young male:2 â€¢ Young female: 2 â€¢ Bargo tribe: 1 â€¢ Hawsa: 2 â€¢ IDPs: 4 2.1: Internal review and workshops were conducted and 5 new areas for the community based management mechanisms for natural re-sources were identified. Through the comprehen-sive discussion with PDCs and the IPs, rehabilita-tion of 2 water points, 2 veterinary centres and construction of vegetable farms and water points were initiated and prioritised. 2.2: A total of 6 community improvement projects were completed in all three states within 2014. In Tawilla, implementation delayed due to the poor performance of the IP in North Darfur, new IP selected and the project made some good progress on the ground. With the no cost extension received, extending the duration of the project to the end of June 2014, the project succeeded to achieve 95% of this output. 2.3: Focus g

target.comment: 1.1 5 additional CBRM councils functional, including in Katila 1.2 50 % of community members have access to CBRMs of which at least 40% are female and vulnerable youth. 2.1 5 community based management mechanisms for natural resources established 2.2 At least 5 community social service infrastructure rehabilitated/ constructed 2.3 50 % of community members stating an increase in the number of interactions between diverse communities through basic services 3.1 3 collective interactions of conflict resolution mechanisms with state and regional level mechanisms 3.2 3 collective interactions of conflict resolutions mechanisms with higher level mechanism

actual.comment: 1.1 Target exceeded. A total of 6 CBRMs were established in Q1 and Q2 of 2015, including in Katila. 1.2 Target exceeded. CBRMs are accessible by the around 26,700 community members. This represents about 90 % of community members in the targeted communities. Perception survey conducted in Mukjar indicated that 90% of community members have access to CBRMS in the project target areas of which 60% are female. (source perception survey) 2.1Target achieved.Three (3) Joint Management Committees (JMC) have been established; one for managing the water well in Mukjar, one for managing the community farm of Kormondo and one for hand dug well in Birgi return village. Two more mechanisms are planned to be established before the end of the year. 2.2 Target exceeded. Total of seven Social service infrastructures have been established / rehabilitated including Two (2) new hand dug wells established in Bergi and Mukjar and one (1) hand dug well in Mukjar, One (1) Livelihood Centre Constructed in Mukjar and one Women Peace Centre at Katilla locality has been constructed, One (1) water station has rehabilitated in Damba village in Kubum Locality and One (1) bakery for food processing was established. 2.3 Target achieved. According to the perception survey conducted in September 2015, 84 % of the community members stated that there is an increase in the interaction between the communities due to establishment of the water points, vegetable farms, distribution of incomes generating sources and tools. 3.1 Target achieved. In 2015, 4 events for collective interaction of conflict resolution mechanisms included: One (1) consultative meeting was held with the Centre for Peace and Development of the University of Nyala and Three (3) workshops on Conflict analysis, Peace building and Conflict Transformation were conducted in Nyala, El Fasher and Zalingei. 3.2 Target achieved.Three Training of Trainer (TOT) workshops on Peacebuilding and Conflict Management and Transformation were cond

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description:
1. Number of regional Sudan Conflict Management Action Group (SCMAGs) established and functioning with adequate youth and women representation.
2. Number of states covered with threat and risk mapping assessments. No or %. of states integrating social threat/risk mapping recommendations endorsed and analysis used in planning and decision making.
3. TRMA information management tools disseminated and used in the target states and managed at state level by national staff.
4. SCMAG analysis and TRMA information utilized in programme development across the UNDP portfolio.

baseline.comment:
1. Weak or non-existent conflict management structures (SCMAG) at state and national levels.
2. 6 states (North) covered with threat and risk mapping assessments. 0 threats and risks identified and integrated into state analysis and planning.
3. Weak or non-existent information management systems in the target states.
4. Interface between TRMA and UNDP programme portfolio to to be reviewed in leu of BCPR assessment.

target.comment: Project closed.

location.name: El Fasher
location.description: seat of a first-order administrative division

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1. Increase in revenue collection 2. Number of institutions at state and locality level with computerized payroll system 3. Number of SSP reviewed and prioritized for three states

baseline.comment: 1. Local revenue too low amounting to only 15% (ND), 20% (SD) and 3.5% (WD) of total revenue receipts in 2009 (ND) and 2010 (SD & WD). 2. No Standard guidelines for revenue collection and reporting in place. 3. Budget departments facing difficulties to apply the GFS as it was imposed from the national Government without provision of requisite training. 4. Payroll is done manually resulting in errors and huge payroll arrears. 5. Strategic planning is still at its infancy and therefore needs strengthening.

target.comment:
1. Revenue collection & Reporting 1.1 100 booklets/guidelines developed & distributed to localities 1.2 10 teams applying GFS system in selected localities for the year.
2. Budget preparation & Management 2.1 20 line ministries & 10 selected localities prepare GFS conform budget. 2.2 90 staff from line ministries and pilot localities trained on GFS.
3. Accounting & reporting systems developed 3.1 40% at line ministries & 20% at localities level decrease in reporting inconsistencies 3.2 20 line ministries & 10 selected localities apply the adopted GFS system after training.
4. Payroll Management & Control 4.1 5 State Ministries of Finance equipped with computerized payroll system 4.2 5 payroll audits conducted
5. Planning & local development fund 5.1 SSP 2012-2016 reviewed for three states & new SSP prepared for 2 states. 5.2 Guide for Strategic Planning Developed & 100 copies distributed 5.3 200 staff trained

actual.comment: 297 participants were exposed to principles of improved revenue collection and reporting The guidelines on financial procedure and budgeting processes were produced in West Darfur and were distributed to stakeholders. 40% at line ministries and 20% at localities level decreased in reporting inconsistencies 20 line ministries and 10 selected localities applied the adopted GFS system Three State ministries equipped and automated payroll system functional. The total number of staff trained in various aspects of project planning, management and evaluation was 226 (79 females and 147 males), exceeding the annual target of 200. In West Darfur, a payroll audit team has been established and payroll audit conducted

target.comment:
Output 1 10% increase in local revenue collection 100 booklets/guidelines developed & distributed to localities 10 teams applying GFS system in selected localities for the year
Output 2 10 line ministries and 10 selected localities prepare GFS conforming budget 90 staff from line ministries and pilot localities trained on GFS.
Output 3 20% of line ministries and 20% of localities level decrease in reporting inconsistencies 10 line ministries and 10 selected localities apply the adopted GFS system
Output 4 5 State Ministries of Finance equipped with computerized payroll system and routinely using it 1 audit conducted 20% decrease in payroll arrears
Output 5 Guide for strategic planning developed & 100 copies distributed 200 staff at state and locality levels trained on strategic planning process.

actual.comment: Two preliminary audits were undertaken in West and South Darfur

iati-activity.description: The project overall objective is to contribute to achieving aid effectiveness in Sudan through strengthening aid management and aid policy coordination

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description:
Indicators Output1: 1.Number of government staff members o responsible for aid coordination functions whose capacities have significantly been improved 2.Improvement in organizational performance in units of MoFNE responsible for aid coordination (the organizational performance will be monitored through a capacity review in 2014) Indicators Output2: 1. Percentage of programmes included in SAID for which regularly updated M&E data is available 2. Percentage of projects included in SAID for which regularly updated M&E data is available
Indicators Output3:
1. Change in levels and quality of coordination of aid policy between government concerned departments (will be monitored through conducting aid policy coordination studies) 2. Establishment of sustainable government/development partners comprehensive dialogue forum on aid policy and coordination

baseline.comment:
Baseline output1: 1. Following the government restructure in 2012, the government Directorates responsible for aid management and coordination have been organized according to new institutional and coordination set up in the government. 2. Capacities of government officials responsible for aid management and coordination needs to be further developed to manage aid coordination after government restructuring 3. No comprehensive capacity assessment has been carried out for the government units and staff members responsible for aid management and coordination. 4. No comprehensive capacity development plan has been developed and implemented for the government units and staff members responsible for aid management and coordination
Baseline Output2: 1. SAID project module has been completed successfully. 2. SAID Fund Expectation module has been completed. 3. SAID programme and aid effectiveness modules have not been completed 4. Aid M&E and information systems are not integrated and harmonized
Baseline Output3:
1. Government aid policy coordination between relevant directorates of the MoFNE (budget, policies, aid management and coordination and development directorates) needs strengthening especially after the government restructuring 2. There are no sufficient aid dialogue and coordination structures including government and development partners 3. A draft Sudan Aid Strategy has been formulated

target.comment: Output 1: 110 key and junior government staff members responsible for aid coordination and management trained in Aid Management and Coordination Output 2: 2.1. 100% of programmes included in SAID which are regularly updated from functioning M&E system 2.2. 100% of projects included in SAID which are regularly updated from functioning M&E system 2.3. SAID includes data on development loans 2.4. SAID available online Output 3: 3.1. The Aid Strategy Document reviewed by government and development partners and endorsed 3.2. Terms of Reference and membership for sustainable government/development partners comprehensive dialogue forums on aid policy developed and coordination established

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description:
1.1 # of criminal justice forums established and frequency of meetings 1.2 # justice strategy plans roll out for the prosecutor 1.3 # of joint training sessions conducted on the human rights approach for justice sector officials 1.4 # of joint training sessions conducted on strategic planning processes for justice sector officials 1.5 # of joint training sessions on budgeting processes conducted for justice sector officials # of legal aid provider clients (individual and communities) disaggregated by gender (% of women) assisted with legal aid counselling 1.2.1: # of refresher courses for GoS prisons officers on human rights approach to prisons management and # of training courses for newly recruited prisons officers for a total of # participants 1.2.2: # of water tanks constructed to address water needs of selected prisons 1.2.3: #of vocational and livelihood skills training workshops established and type of tools and equipment procured 1.3.1. .#of capacity development trainings, including strategic planning conducted for police officers 1.3.2. #civilian oversight mechanisms in place 1.4.1: #of capacity development trainings conducted to Sudan National Human Rights Commission staff and key stakeholders 1.4.2: New committee in Darfur established and strategic priorities for Darfur defined 1.5.1. # of relevant government officials have improved their knowledge in human rights, and improved the implementation of Sudan obligations under human rights treaties 1.5. 2. Number of capacity building workshops to support revision of laws in line with Sudanâ€™s record regarding harmonization of legislation with international obligations 1.5.3: UPR Action Plan reviewed/finalized, with attribution/development of specific sets of indicators and timelines 2.1.1: % of people expressing high confidence in and easy access to rule of law institutions disaggregated by gender disaggregated by state
2.1.2: : # of legal aid provider clients (individual and communities) disaggreg

baseline.comment: 1. Two criminal justice forums established at regional level (one in Darfur and one in eastern Sudan) and quarterly meetings held 2. 100 complaints received and no data on caseload age 3. No office existing outside of Khartoum 4. 300 representatives of the judiciary, prosecutors, police and prison staff and social workers trained in human rights and 47 social workers 5. 82 parliamentarians and legal advisors trained on importance of law reform for child law and womenâ€™s law 6. UPR action Plan for the UPR process developed 7. 30% of people report high confidence in and easy access to rule of law institutions overall; 20% women report high confidence; 22% reported easy access (2013) 8. 4 Legal aid network (LAN) organizations and 4 JCCs in Darfur were fully functional and active during 2013 9. Two legal aid desks established in the selected prisons in Darfur but not yet effectively functional 10. There is little knowledge on the alternative dispute resolution mechanisms 11.Limited monitoring visits to support project implementation by staff

target.comment: 1. Two criminal justice forums established at regional level (one in Darfur and one in eastern Sudan) and quarterly meetings held 2. 6 strategic planning sessions provided to selected justice sector institutions 3. 70% of citizens report confidence in and easy access to rule of law institutions 4. 6 refresher courses for GoS prisons officers on human rights approach to prisons management and 6 training courses for newly recruited prisons officers conducted in all five Darfur states for 300 participants 5. 1 underground water tank (250,000 liters) and 1 elevated water tank (40,000 liters) constructed at Shallah Federal Prison in El Fasher to address water needs 6. 6 vocational and livelihood skills training workshops established and tools and equipment for welding and metal works, carpentry, masonry, auto-mechanics, and tailoring procured in 6 Darfur prisons (Shallah Federal Prison in El Fasher; Kheir Khanaga Women Prison in El Fasher; Central Prison in Nyala; Ardamata Prison in El Geneina; Zalingei Prison; and El Daein Prison 7. # senior police management and leadership M/F trained on strategic planning 8. Civilian Oversight Mechanisms drafted through 2 consultations and workshops 9. Special committee on Darfur in place and strategic priorities for Darfur established 10. 200 relevant government officials have improved their human rights knowledge and enhanced the implementation of Sudan obligations under human Rights treaties 11. Progress towards revision of 4 laws (Child Act, Press Act, Criminal Act and law related to womenâ€™s rights) 12. Sets of indicators and timelines to monitor UPR implementation progress developed and included into the UPR Action Plan 13. 50% report high confidence overall; 30% women report high confidence; 30% report easy access. 14. Target: 300 clients (30% women) assisted with legal aid counselling at the 8 existing JCCs across Darfur and 150 clients in eastern Sudan 15. 10 NGOs and CBOs participating in access to justice trainings

actual.comment:
1) Overall progress for output 1: improve justice, security and human rights provided by state actors through more effective, equitable and timely protection services: Implementation of activities to improve the capacity of Justice, Security and human Rights Institutions is progressing well. Vocational training were developed and delivered with the participation of various stakeholders including UNAMID, Police and Prison Section with government ministries (Prosecutor, Prison and Police). Implementation of the 5 Year Strategic plan for prison development is progressing well (17F & 113M) prison officers benefited from Human rights approach to prisons management for prison officers. Fair trial and legal aid related principles have been incorporated into training models for prosecutors and lawyers (123F & 267M). Similarly, management and leadership skills, criminal investigation, with focus SGBV were delivered to police officers (8F & 56M). To increase the extension of police service Community policing volunteers training models were delivered with the participation of IDPs, community leaders, women groups, youth (445F & 356M). Special efforts have also been made improve Darfur Transitional Justice institutions to fight impunity and promote reconciliation with a Witness and Victims Protection Strategy along with UNAMID Human Rights Section. Implementation of UPR Recommendations is progressing well. Data collection around the implementation of UPR is showing that 85% of UPR Recommendations have been implemented, with the amendment of Criminal Law, Election Law and the adoption of Human Trafficking Law and Access to Information Law and Regulation of Refugees Law. Access to legal aid and protection for vulnerable groups strengthened
2) Overall progress for Output 2: Access to legal aid and protection for vulnerable groups strengthened : With the goal of scaling up the provision of legal aid and enhance legal awareness efforts in multiple provinces in five Darfur States an

1.1 Complaints Committee established and has begun working, but administrative staff acts as intake officer and registrar 1.2: There is no structured workflow for case management life cycle in SNHRC 1.3: No complaints management manual 1.4: No feasibility study has been conducted 1,5 No automated case management system in place 1.6 Gender disaggregation of caseload is currently 20% female and 80% males cases 1.7 . TBC

target.comment:
4.1: Complaints committee reviewed to assumes oversight and governance role; position of registrar established 4.2: Complaints management process flow is designed for entire case management life cycle 4.3: Caseload processing manuals are developed for intake, investigations, referrals, reporting, urgent cases, confidentiality, and systemic cases 4..4 Feasibility study on CM finalized 4.5 Automated case management system installed and in place 4.6 Gender disaggregation of caseload become 50% female and 50% males cases 4.7 . TBE
Targets for Output 2:
2.1: Special committee on Darfur in place and Strategic priorities for Darfur set 2: 2 One workshop on joint human rights cooperation framework 2.3 Four meetings of the Darfur Human Rights Forum with Gos, ACHR, SNHRC, donors, UN agencies, CSOs 2.4: Ten meetings at the local level to address key human rights concerns
Targets for Output 3:
3.1. All staff (112 staff 40% of whom are females ) received training on core operational policies; At least 10 trainings courses conducted on case management. 3.2. TBC (Key internal administrative and operational policies in place)

actual.comment:
Overall progress of output 4: Complaint Management infrastructure strengthened: internal regulations of the Complaints Committee revised with oversight and governance role of the Complaints Committee, with Complaints Manual and standard forms covering the management process for the entire life cycle of a case have been developed. In order to increase the visibility of the SNHRC and of the Complaints Committee in particular, an outreach programme was organized for 70 people, including over 10 members of the media.
Overall Progress of Output 5 Engagement in Darfur: Workshop was organized in Khartoum with representatives from Darfur, UNAMID Human rights Section to establish the new Committee on Darfur and define its road map or strategic plan for the opening of the SNHRC in Darfur, and arrangements are underway to launch the Darfur Branch in December
Overall Progress of output 6: Commissioners and staff capacity to perform respective functions through the delivery of targeted training and professional developed: Significant results have been achieved in developing internal policies. A two-day training for the Commissioners and the staff of the Complaints Committee was held, and 7 operational policies were developed: 1 internal regulation and 3 key operational procedures for the Complaints Committee (as annexes to the Complaints Manual) ; 1 ethics/conflict of interest policy; 1 Staff Recruitment policy; 1 job description template

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1. Percentage of new arrivals receiving food assistance. 2. Percentage of sites with a GAM rate of under 15%. 3. # of refugees, asylum seekers and South Sudanese registered on an individual basis. 4. # of those identified as at risk of statelessness are assisted with advocacy, counselling or help to obtain documentation.

baseline.comment: Sudan hosts around 171,000 refugees and asylum seekers from a range of countries: Eritrea, Ethiopia, Chad, (CAR), the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC), Somalia and Syria. Around 92,000 live in eastern Sudan, another 32,000 in Khartoum, and around 45,000 in Darfur. Sudan also has over 90,000 Sudanese in Darfur who were previously refugees in Chad, and have now returned to their country of origin, but not all to their area of origin. Finally, there are also potentially 350,000 individuals of South Sudanese origin (of which around 40,000 reside in Khartoum) who had been living in Sudan prior to secession that did not flee conflict. They have an unclear legal status and so are potentially at risk of statelessness.

target.comment: 1. 70% 2. 100% 3. South Sudanese: 100% East Sudan: 80% Khartoum: 0% Darfur: 80% 4. 45,000

indicator.description: 1. Number of people, including women and children, receiving individual or community-based psychosocial support and services. 2. Number of USAMs, as well as other children in need of protection (such as children survivors of sexual and other physical violence) who are identified, documented, provided with interim care or reunified. 3. Number of active communitybased protection committees identified/created and supported (including thematic committees on child protection and SGBV, child friendly centres and women centres). 4. Number of supplies distributed to extremely vulnerable women (PHK & sanitary materials).

baseline.comment: Since 2014, Sudan has witnessed an upsurge in conflict-induced displacement. In order to address the needs of these newly displaced people, as well as those people who have been displaced for a number of years, the protection sector has identified a number of priority areas to guide interventions in 2015. These interventions will be carried out in collaboration with the Government of Sudan, relevant protection institutions and humanitarian organisations.
